DT Article
TI The genus Corvospongilla Annandale, 1911 (Porifera: Demospongiae:
   Spongillida) from Madagascar freshwater with description of a new
   species: biogeographic and evolutionary aspects.
AU Manconi, Renata (rmanconi@uniss.it) 
   Pronzato, Roberto
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 4
PS 544-554
PD May 31 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB We report here the first record of five genera of Spongillida (Porifera,
   Demospongiae) in both lentic and lotic water of Madagascar and the
   discovery of a new species of the genus Corvospongilla from the
   Betsiboka River hydrographic basin. Corvospongilla lemuriensis sp. n.
   diverges from all the other known species of the genus in its unique
   combination of diagnostic morphotraits (a) sessile gemmules with
   chambered pneumatic layer within tri-layered theca and enveloped by
   spicular cage of dominant acanthostrongyles, (b) dominant
   acanthostrongyles and less frequent acanthoxeas-strongyloxeas as
   megascleres and gemmuloscleres. The new species is characterised by the
   exclusive presence of a well-developed pneumatic layer in sessile
   gemmules not described for the genus until now. The new record confirms
   a Gondwanian track for the genus Corvospongilla and increases the
   knowledge on Spongillida historical biogeography. In synthesis the
   present discovery of Corvospongilla in the Malagasy biogeographic
   province (a) contributes to the assessment of Afrotropical biodiversity,
   (b) enlarges the geographic range of the genus reducing its disjunct
   distribution, and (c) focus on the evolutionary history of adaptive
   morphofunctional traits of resting bodies and life cycle timing in
   ephemeral water of the south-eastern Austral hemisphere.
C1 Manconi, Renata; Univ Sassari, Dipartimento Med Vet, Via Vienna 2,
   Sassari, I-07100, Italy, Italy.
EM rmanconi@uniss.it
RI Manconi, Renata/AAD-9292-2019
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Evolution; Zoogeography;
   Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Corvospongilla [Evolution /  / systematics; biodiversity] [Zoogeography
   / Biogeography / ] [Madagascar /  / distribution] [ /  / New record]. 
   Corvospongilla lemuriensis [Madagascar /  / New species]. 
   Ephydatia; Eunapius; Radiospongilla; Trochospongilla [Madagascar /  /
   New record]. 
TN Invertebrates; Sponges
ST Animalia, Porifera, Demospongiae
OR Corvospongilla - Annandale 1911 (Demospongiae): [Emended diagnosis, P.
   546; New record]. 
   Corvospongilla lemuriensis (Demospongiae): [Sp nov, Madagascar, P. 546].
   
   Ephydatia (Demospongiae): [New record]. 
   Eunapius (Demospongiae): [New record].

DT Article
TI A new species of Acanthosaura Gray 1831 (Reptilia: Agamidae) from
   central Vietnam.
AU Sang Ngoc Nguyen
   Jin, Jie-Qiong
   Ba Dinh Vo
   Luan Thanh Nguyen
   Zhou, Wei-Wei
   Che, Jing
   Murphy, Robert W. (ngocsangitb@yahoo.com) 
   Zhang, Ya-Ping
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 4
PS 555-565
PD May 31 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 3
AB Herein, we describe the new agamid species Acanthosaura phongdienensis
   sp. nov. from central Vietnam based on morphological and genetic data.
   Males of the new medium-sized species have a snout-vent length of up to
   77.4 mm and females up to 64.7 mm. In both genders, the tail is longer
   than the snout-vent length. A spine occurs on each side of the neck, the
   rostral scute is entire, and the nuchal and dorsal crests are
   continuous. A postorbital spine is about half as long as the diameter of
   the eye-ball, and small lateral scales intermix with large, keeled
   scales whose tips point backwards and upwards. The new species differs
   genetically from the closely related species A. brachypoda, A. coronata,
   and A. lepidogaster by uncorrected p-distances of 13.6%, 21.7%, and
   12.8%, respectively. This is the 13th species of Acanthosaura and the
   eighth species in the genus from Vietnam.
C1 Murphy, Robert W.; Chinese Acad Sci, Kunming Inst Zool, 32 Jiaochang
   Donglu, Kunming, Yunnan, 650223, China, China.
EM ngocsangitb@yahoo.com
RI Thanh, Luan Nguyen/AAB-5686-2020; Phong, KHCN-HTQT/AAJ-5480-2020
OI Nguyen, Luan/0000-0002-4663-125X
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Acanthosaura phongdienensis [Vietnam /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Agamidae
OR Acanthosaura phongdienensis (Agamidae): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 559].

DT Article
TI A new species of Deutella Mayer 1890 (Crustacea: Amphipoda) from the
   Mexican Pacific coast.
AU Alarcon-Ortega, Lucy C. (coral.alarcono@gmail.com) 
   Carballo, Jose L.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 4
PS 581-590
PD May 31 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of caprellid, Deutella mazatlanensis n. sp., is described
   from Mazatlan Bay, (east Pacific Mexico). Deutella mazatlanensis was
   found associated with blyozoans, hydroids and sponges in shallow waters.
   The new species can be differentiated from the remaining species of the
   genus mainly by the dorsal, anteriorly directed projection on the head;
   the two dorsal projections and a lateral acute projection
   anteroventrally projected on pereonite 2 and gnathopod 2 in males. The
   presence of this species on the Mexican Pacific coast, constitutes the
   fourth report of Deutella genus for the Pacific Ocean and the first
   record from the tropical Eastern Pacific.
C1 Alarcon-Ortega, Lucy C.; Univ Nacl Autonoma Mexico, Inst Ciencias Mar &
   Limnol ICMyL, Ave Joel Montes Camarena S-N,Cerro Vigia POB 811,
   Mazatlan, 82040, Mexico, Mexico.
EM coral.alarcono@gmail.com
RI Carballo, Jose Luis/C-3198-2018; Alarcon, Lucy/AAE-8771-2019
OI Carballo, Jose Luis/0000-0002-5146-7597; Alarcon,
   Lucy/0000-0001-5228-6256

SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

TI A new species of Caroperla Kohno, 1946 (Plecoptera: Perlidae) from
   Guangxi of China.
AU Mo, Raorao
   Wang, Guoquan (wangguoquan0@163.com) 
   Li, Weihai
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 4
PS 591-594
PD May 31 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB One new species of the genus Caroperla Kohno, C. longilobata sp. nov.,
   is described from the Dayao Mountain of Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region
   of southern China The relationships of morphological characteristics of
   the new species and the three-known species of the genus are discussed.

DT Article
TI [On a Toarcian fauna (Brachiopoda and Bivalvia) from Alos de Balaguer
   (Prov. Lerida. NE Spain).]
FT Sobre una faunula toarciense (Brachiopoda y Bivalvia) de Alos de
   Balaguer (Prov. Lerida. NE Espana).
AU Calzada, Sebastian
   Francisco Carrasco, Jose
SO Scripta Musei Geologici Seminarii Barcinonensis Series Palaeontologica
VL 24
PS 6-14
PD May 30 2019
PY 2019
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Several brachiopods and bivalves coming from the Toarcian or next stages
   of Alos de Balaguer (Lerida Prov., NE. Spain) are studied. Specifically:
   Brachiopoda: Telothyris jauberti, Lobothyris punctata and Homoeorhynchia
   meridonalis batalleri. Bivalvia: Gryphaea cymbium, Pholadomya sp. and
   Pterocardia sp. The genus Pterocardia is cited in Spain for the first
   time.

   Barcelona, 08007, Spain, Spain.

DT Article
TI Detection of the amoebic parasite (order Dactylopodida) in cultured
   Pacific white shrimp (Litopenaeus vannamei).
AU Han, Jee Eun (jehan@knu.ac.kr) 
SO Aquaculture
VL 507
PS 246-250
PD May 30 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 3
U2 6
AB This study describes the amoeba (order Dactylopodida) infection in
   Pacific white shrimp Litopenaeus vannamei cultured in an anonymous
   shrimp hatchery, located in North America. The diseased shrimp grossly
   exhibited reduced appetite, lethargy, respiratory distress, eroded
   carapace, and blackened gill. Histopathology examination revealed a
   massive amoeba infection (mostly in trophozoite form) mainly in the
   gill, but also other organs, such as the antennal gland, lymphoid organ,
   appendages, and nerve cord of the studied shrimp. The irregular-shaped
   trophozoites, with the prominent centrally located nucleolus and the
   basophilic parasome, suggested that this parasite is related to the
   Paramoeba sp. (order Dactylopodida). Analysis of the small subunit rRNA
   sequence showed 100% sequence similarity with Paramoeba spp. (or
   Neoparamoeba spp.) from several aquatic crustaceans and echinoderm
   species, such as sea urchins, crabs, and lobsters. The sequence also
   matched with other amoeba species, such as Korotnevella sp. and
   Pseudoparamoeba sp. (order Dactylopodida). Diagnostic in situ
   hybridization and PCR assays were developed as the initial screening
   methods for the detection of the amoebic infection in cultured shrimp.
   This report is the first to describe the amoeba (Paramoeba-like sp.)
   infection in penaeid shrimp.
C1 Han, Jee Eun; Kyungpook Natl Univ, Coll Vet Med, Daegu, 41566, South
   Korea, South Korea.
EM jehan@knu.ac.kr
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Genetics
   &Heredity
SN 0044-8486
BD Genetics; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Ecology;
   Population dynamics; Land zones; USA; Oceanic islands; Pacific Ocean
   islands
DE Litopenaeus vannamei [Protozoan parasites / Paramoeba / Host parasite
   relationships; new record; pathology; infection rate] [Mortality /  / ]
   [Hawaii /  / ]. 
   Paramoeba [Molecular genetics / SSU rRNA sequences / host parasite
   relationships; new record; pathology; infection rate] [Crustacean hosts
   / Litopenaeus vannamei / ] [Hawaii /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates; Protozoans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Natantia, Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Rhizopoda,
   Lobosea, Gymnamoebia, Amoebida
OR Litopenaeus vannamei (Natantia): [Host; New record]. 
   Paramoeba (Amoebida): [Parasite; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15509060206

DT Article
TI The Eastern Palaearctic Cosmopterix feminella Sinev, 1988, introduced in
   Italy: taxonomy, biology and a new synonymy (Lepidoptera,
   Cosmopterigidae).
AU Koster, Sjaak J.C. (sjaak.koster@naturalis.nl) 
   Baldizzone, Giorgio
   Deutsch, Helmut
   Huemer, Peter
   van Nieukerken, Erik J.
SO Nota Lepidopterologica
VL 42
IS 1
PS 49-61
PD May 30 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Cosmopterix feminella Sinev, 1988, previously known from the East
   Palearctic, Primorskiy Territory in Russia and Japan has been collected
   at light in Europe. In northern Italy 58 females were collected in two
   localities in the province Asti, two in Alessandria, three in Udine, and
   in one locality in Pordenone. Cosmopterix feminella is most likely
   parthenogenetic as only females are known. The caterpillars are
   leafminers on grasses. The species is redescribed and illustrated. DNA
   barcodes are provided and compared with other European species.
   Cosmopterix feminae Kuroko, 2015 is synonymised with C. feminella. The
   species was probably accidentally introduced into Italy.
C1 Koster, Sjaak J.C.; Nat Biodivers Ctr, POB 9557, Leiden, NL-2300 RA,
   Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM sjaak.koster@naturalis.nl
RI van Nieukerken, Erik/B-4512-2012
OI van Nieukerken, Erik/0000-0002-5721-1840
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology
SN 0342-7536
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Synonymy; Genetics;
   Zoogeography; Dispersal; Means of dispersal; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Cosmopterix feminella [Molecular genetics / DNA barcodes / new record;
   systematics] [Introduction /  / ] [Europe /  / biology] [Italy /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Gelechioidea, Cosmopterigidae
OR Cosmopterix feminella - Sinev 1988 (Cosmopterigidae): [Redescription, P.
   51; Syn nov, Cosmopterix feminae Kuroko 2015, p. 58; New record].

DT Article
TI A new species of Astropecten (Echinodermata: Asteroidea: Paxillosida:
   Astropectinidae) and a comparison of the Astropecten species from the
   Gulf of Mexico and the East Florida Shelf.
AU Cobb, Janessa C. (Janessa.Fletcher@MyFWC.com) 
   Lawrence, John M.
   Herrera, Joan C.
   Lopez, Karen
   Janies, Daniel
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 3
PS 301-325
PD May 30 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Astropecten is described, supported by morphological
   and molecular evidence, from the Gulf of Mexico and the East Florida
   Shelf with most specimens from 30-60 m in depth. The new species, A.
   mcedwardi n. sp., is small, with a maximum major radius < 30 mm.
   Specimens of A. mcedwardi n. sp. have been found in five museums as an
   undescribed species or misidentified under several names. The spination
   of the oral surface most closely resembles that of Astropecten
   antillensis Liitken, 1859 from the Caribbean, but the body form is
   similar to that of Astropecten duplicatus Gray, 1840, which is found in
   the same geographic range. Examination of specimens from different
   collections indicates that the new species may overlap in distribution
   withA. antillensis along the East Florida Shelf. Sequencing and
   phylogenetic analysis of two mitochondrial genes reveal that A.
   mcedwardi is closely related to A. antillensis but that its phylogenetic
   lineage is distinct from that of A. antillensis.
C1 Cobb, Janessa C.; Florida Fish & Wildlife Conservat Commiss, Specimen
   Collect, 100 8th Ave SE, St Petersburg, FL, 33701, USA, USA.
EM Janessa.Fletcher@MyFWC.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Marine zones;
   Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Astropecten [North Atlantic / USA, Florida, East Florida Shelf / Key to
   species] [Caribbean Sea / North / ] [Gulf of Mexico /  / ]. 
   Astropecten mcedwardi [North Atlantic / USA, Florida / New species]
   [Gulf of Mexico /  / ] [ /  / ]. 
TN Echinoderms; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Echinodermata, Stelleroidea, Asteroidea
OR Astropecten - Gray 1840 (Asteroidea): [Key to species, Caribbean Sea,
   North, Gulf of Mexico & North Atlantic, USA, Florida, East Florida
   Shelf, P. 319]. 
   Astropecten mcedwardi (Asteroidea): [Sp nov, USA, Florida (marine), P.
   303].

DT Article
TI New records and new species of mites from Cuba, with description of a
   new genus of Laelapidae (Acari: Mesostigmata).
AU Joharchi, Omid (J.omid2000@gmail.com) 
   Halliday, Bruce
   Tolstikov, Andrei, V
   Trach, Viacheslav A.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 3
PS 326-350
PD May 30 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper presents a new genus, two new species, and several new
   records of mites associated with insects and soil in Cuba. A new
   monotypic genus of Laelapidae, Acantholaelaps gen. nov., is described to
   accommodate a new species, A. strategus sp. nov., on the basis of adult
   female and male specimens collected on Strategus sarpedon (Burmeister)
   (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae) and Strategus surinamensis hirtus Sternberg
   (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae). The other species recorded were Macrocheles
   merdarius (Berlese) (Macrochelidae), Asca quinquesetosa Wharton
   (Ascidae), Gaeolaelaps cubaensis sp. nov. (Laelapidae) and
   Pseudoparasitus missouriensis (Ewing) (Laelapidae).

DT Article
TI Four new species of Plega Navas, 1928 (Neuroptera: Mantispidae) from
   Mexico.
AU Ardila-Camacho, Adrian
   Cancino-Lopez, Rodolfo J.
   Acevedo, Fernando
   Contreras-Ramos, Atilano (aardilac88@gmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 3
PS 351-372
PD May 30 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Four new species of Plega Navas, 1928 (Mantispidae: Symphrasinae) from
   Mexico are herein described and illustrated, namely P. mixteca sp. n.
   from Oaxaca and Jalisco, P. stangei sp. n. from Morelos and Oaxaca, P.
   sonorae sp. n. from Sonora, and P. spinosa sp. n. from Guerrero,
   Jalisco, Morelos, Nayarit, Oaxaca, Puebla, and Veracruz. Including these
   new species, Plega's diversity raises to 17 described species, of which
   12 are recorded from Mexico, and one of them, Plega variegata Navas,
   1928, is herein proposed as nomen dubium. A taxonomic key to the known
   species of Plega from Mexico is provided.
C1 Contreras-Ramos, Atilano; UNAM, Inst Biol, Ciudad Univ, Mexico City, DF,
   04510, Mexico, Mexico.
EM aardilac88@gmail.com
RI Acevedo Ramos, Fernando/E-1842-2018
OI Acevedo Ramos, Fernando/0000-0001-7508-7807

SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   zones; Nearctic region; North America

   New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates

DT Article
TI On some new and old soft scale insects (Hemiptera: Coccomorpha:
   Coccidae) from Africa, with description of a new Coccus species and
   introduction of a new genus.
AU Lagowska, Bozena (bozena.lagowska@up.lublin.pl) 
   Hodgson, Chris J.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 3
PS 373-386
PD May 30 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of soft scale (Hemiptera: Coccomorpha; Cocccidae) from
   South Africa. Coccus giliomeei Lagowska & Hodgson sp. n., collected on
   Gymnosporia buxifolia (L.) Szyszyl, is described and illustrated. Also,
   Coccus rhodesiensis (Hall) is recorded for the first time from South
   Africa and is redescribed and illustrated based on the adult females of
   the type series and fresh South African specimens. An updated key to the
   species of Coccus and similar species known from Africa is included.
   Based on this latter study, (i) Marsipococcus proteae (Brain) and M.
   durbanensis (Brain) are considered not to be congeneric with
   Marsipococcus marsupialis (Green), the type species of Marsipococcus
   Cockerell & Bueker, and are placed in a new genus Proteacoccus Lagowska
   & Hodgson, gen. n. with Lecanium proteae Brain as the type species; (ii)
   it is considered that Coccus asiaticus Lindinger is clearly not a junior
   synonym of Parasaissetia nigra (Nietner) and is accepted as a full
   species, rev. stilt., and (iii) Neoplatylecanium adersi (Newstead) is
   considered to be non-conspecific with N. cinnamomi Takahashi, the type
   species of Neoplatylecanium Takahashi. and is transferred to Maacoccus
   Tao & Wong, as Maacoccus adersi (Newstead), comb.n.
C1 Lagowska, Bozena; Univ Life Sci Lublin, Dept Entomol, Ul Leszczynskiego
   7, Lublin, PL-20069, Poland, Poland.
EM bozena.lagowska@up.lublin.pl

TI Description of two new genera of Ochlerini (Hemiptera: Pentatomidae:
   Discocephalinae).
AU Garbelotto, Thereza De A. (therezagarbelotto@hotmail.com) 
   Grazia, Jocelia
   Campos, Luiz Alexandre
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 3
PS 387-400
PD May 30 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Since the phylogenetic analysis of the Herrichella Glade (Ochlerini) new
   genera were described to fit monophyletic groups inferred and considered
   to be new taxa. The clade I supported by two synapomorphies of the
   female genitalia, grouped Alitocoris brunneus Sailer together to two new
   species. Alloeogyna gen. nov. is described here for this Glade including
   the two new species Alloeogyna ampla sp. nov. and Alloeogyna poecila sp.
   nov. and a new combination is proposed for Alloeogyna brunnea comb.
   nov.. Also, Alitocoris maculosus Sailer recovered within the Glade E in
   the Herrichella Glade is here redescribed in the monotypic Sailerus gen.
   nov. resulting in the new combination Sailerus maculosus comb. nov..

TI A taxonomic study on Themus (Telephorops) davidis species-group
   (Coleoptera, Cantharidae), with description of a new species from China.
AU Yang, Yuxia
   Zong, Le
   Yang, Xingke (yxyang@hbu.edu.cn) 
   Liu, Haoyu
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 3
PS 401-411
PD May 30 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB Themus (Telephorops) davidis species-group is redefined and we present a
   catalogue, identification key and distribution map for this group. Some
   previously known species are redescribed and we provide new
   illustrations of female internal genitalia, abdominal sternite VIII
   and/or aedeagus. Further, we report new distribution data. A new
   species, Themus (Telephorops) hainanus sp. nov. from China (Hainan) is
   described, and Themus (Telephorops) birmanicus Widmer, 1983 is recorded
   from China for the first time.

DT Article
TI New records of eumenine wasps (Hymenoptera: Vespidae: Eumeninae ) from
   Russia with description of a new species of Leptochilus de Saussure,
   1853.
AU Fateryga, Alexander, V (fater_84@list.ru) 
   Mokrousov, Mikhail, V
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 3
PS 412-422
PD May 30 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB New additions to the knowledge of the subfamily Eumeninae in Russia are
   provided. Leptochilus (Lionotulus) leleji Fateryga, sp. nov. is
   described fromAltai Republic. Males of Ancistrocerus hangaicus Kurzenko,
   1977 and Jucancistrocerus (Eremodynerus) minutepunctatus Giordani Soika,
   1970 are described for the first time; the latter species is transferred
   from the nominotypical subgenus to the subgenus Eremodynerus Bluthgen,
   1939. The genus Tachyancistrocerus Giordani Soika, 1952 and six species
   of eumenine wasps are reported from Russia for the first time:
   Discoelius pictus Kostylev, 1940a, Euodynerus (Euodynerus) curictensis
   Bluthgen, 1940, E. (E.) hellenicus Bluthgen, 1942, E. (E.) rufinus
   Bluthgen, 1942, Eustenancistrocerus (Eustenancistrocerus) jerichoensis
   (von Schulthess, 1928), and Tachyancistrocerus schmidti (Kokujev, 1913);
   E. hellenicus is also reported from Georgia and Azerbaijan. New regional
   records for nine species are reported. Three species are excluded from
   the fauna of Russia: Eustenancistrocerus (Eustenancistrocerus) tegularis
   (Morawitz, 1885), Odynerus (Odynerus) tristis (Bluthgen, 1939), and
   Stenodynerus aequisculptus (Kostylev, 1940b). The known fauna of Russia
   now numbers 34 genera and 162 species of eumenine wasps.

TI Two new spider species of the genus Conculus (Araneae, Anapidae) from

U1 0

AB Two new species the spider family Anapidae are described from Southeast
   Asia: Conculus sagadaensis n. sp. from Philippines and Conculus yaoi n.
   sp. from Indonesia, both described after male specimens. Conculus is

DT Article
TI A new flower fly species of Cepa Thompson & Vockeroth (Diptera:
   Syrphidae) from the Valdivian evergreen forest hotspot, Chile.
AU Barahona-Segovia, Rodrigo M. (rbarahona13@gmail.com) 
   Barcelo, Matias
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 3
PS 431-439
PD May 30 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The Neotropical region has a high species richness of flower flies.
   However, there are many known species awaiting proper description. Cepa
   Thompson & Vockeroth is a Neotropical genus with scattered records and
   few individuals collected of its three species. In the present study, a
   female of a new species of Cepa is described, C. simonettii
   Barahona-Segovia sp. nov., from the Valdivian evergreen forest
   representing the first record of this genus in Chile. In addition, an
   identification key to all known species of Cepa is provided.
   Morphological and biogeographic aspects of this new Cepa species are
   discussed, as well as the potential phylogenetic relationship with other
   members of Merodontini.
C1 Barahona-Segovia, Rodrigo M.; Univ Chile, Fac Ciencias Vet & Pecuarias,
   Campus Sur, Santiago, Chile, Chile.
EM rbarahona13@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Cepa [Neotropical region /  / Distribution] [Chile /  / New record]. 
   Cepa simonettii [Chile /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Syrphidae
OR Cepa - Thompson & Vockeroth 2007 (Syrphidae): [Key to species, Adapted
   key, p. 435; New record]. 
   Cepa simonettii - Barahona-Segovia 2019 (Syrphidae): [Sp nov, Chile, P.

DT Article
TI Review of the endemic New Zealand genus Arctesthes Meyrick (Lepidoptera,
   Geometridae, Larentiinae), with descriptions of two new range-restricted
   species.
AU Patrick, Brian H.
   Patrick, Hamish J.H.
   Hoare, Robert J.B. (hoarer@landcareresearch.co.nz) 
SO Alpine Entomology
VL 3
PS 121-136
PD May 29 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Arctesthes Meyrick (Geometridae: Larentiinae: Xanthorhoini),
   endemic to the South Island of New Zealand, is revised. Four species are
   recognised, including two new species, as follows: Arctesthes catapyrrha
   (Butler, 1877), A. siris (Hudson, 1908), A. titanica sp. nov. and A.
   avatar sp. nov. All except A. catapyrrha are restricted to subalpine and
   alpine localities. Adults and genitalia are fully described and
   illustrated for all species; larvae of A. catapyrrha are also briefly
   described and illustrated. Only Arctesthes catapyrrha is widespread; A.
   siris is restricted to a few mountain ranges of Central Otago; A.
   titanica is only known from two wetland localities in the Von Valley of
   the Otago Lakes district, and A. avatar is only known from a few
   wetlands in a restricted area of north-west Nelson. The two new species
   are considered of very high priority for conservation.
C1 Hoare, Robert J.B.; Manaaki Whenua Landcare Res, Private Bag 92170,
   Auckland, New Zealand, New Zealand.
EM hoarer@landcareresearch.co.nz
SC Zoology
SN 2535-0889; 2535-0889

   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Land zones; Australasian region; Australasia
DE Arctesthes [New Zealand / South Island / Biology; distribution;
   taxonomic review]. 
   Arctesthes avatar; Arctesthes titanica [New Zealand /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Geometroidea, Geometridae
OR Arctesthes - Meyrick 1885 (Geometridae): [Redescription, P. 122]. 
   Arctesthes avatar (Geometridae): [Sp nov, New Zealand, P. 129]. 
   Arctesthes catapyrrha - (Butler 1877) (Geometridae): [Redescription, P.
   123; Senior synonym, Of Arctesthes catapyrrha kaikourensis Prout 1939,
   p. 123]. 
   Arctesthes catapyrrha form. fasciata - Prout 1939 (Geometridae):
   [Status, P. 126]. 
   Arctesthes catapyrrha kaikourensis - Prout 1939 (Geometridae): [Junior
   synonym, Of Arctesthes catapyrrha (Butler 1877), p. 123]. 
   Arctesthes siris - (Hudson 1908) (Geometridae): [Redescription, P. 126].

   Fidonia? catapyrrha - Butler 1877 (Geometridae): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 123].

AN ZOOR15508053046
DT Article
TI Empidoid flies from Cabo Verde (Diptera, Empidoidea, Dolichopodidae and
   Hybotidae) are not only composed of Old World tropical species.
AU Grootaert, Patrick (pgrootaert@yahoo.co.uk) 
   Van de Velde, Isabella
SO European Journal of Taxonomy
VL 528
PS 1-17
PD May 29 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the present paper three empidoid fly species new to science are
   described from the island Sal of the Cabo Verde archipelago. Aphrosylus
   salensis sp. nov., a marine dolichopodid fly, is found in the splash
   zone of a rocky sea shore. Crossopalpus salensis sp. nov. (Hybotidae) is
   recorded from two different sebkhas. Crossopalpus complicatus sp. nov.
   is reported from an irrigated wasteland. A key to the species of these
   two genera occurring on Cape Verde is provided. The presence of the
   morphospecies Tachytrechus tessellatus (Macquart, 1842), a presumed Old
   World tropical species, is confirmed.
C1 Grootaert, Patrick; Royal Belgian Inst Nat Sci, Vautierstr 29, Brussels,
   B-1000, Belgium, Belgium.
EM pgrootaert@yahoo.co.uk
SC Zoology
SN 2118-9773

   islands; Atlantic Ocean islands
DE Aphrosylus [Afrotropical region /  / Key to species]. 
   Aphrosylus salensis; Crossopalpus complicatus; Crossopalpus salensis
   [Cape Verde /  / New species]. 
   Crossopalpus [Cape Verde /  / Key to species]. 
   Dolichopodidae; Hybotidae [Cape Verde /  / Systematics]. 
   Tachytrechus tessellatus [Cape Verde /  / Confirmation of occurrence].

PT J

PM 31142811
DT Article
TI Integrated data analysis allows the establishment of a new, cosmopolitan
   genus of marine Macrodasyida (Gastrotricha).
AU Todaro, M. Antonio (antonio.todaro@unimore.it) 
   Dal Zotto, Matteo
   Kanneby, Tobias
   Hochberg, Rick
SO Scientific Reports
VL 9
PS 7989
PD May 29 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 2
AB Macrodasyida (phylum Gastrotricha) comprises 365 species distributed
   across 34 genera and 10 families. However, current classification is
   under revision due to the contradictory results of molecular and
   morphological cladistic analyses. Studies aimed at bridging the gaps
   took advantage of supplementary assessments of poorly known species and
   particularly from observations of new taxa showing original traits that
   could help to identify plesiomorphic character states in these
   anatomically diverse micrometazoa. We follow this path by describing
   three new interesting macrodasyidan species respectively from Italy,
   Brazil and Sweden. In many respects, the new species resemble most
   closely species of the genus Macrodasys; however, details of the
   external morphology, in combination with the different lay-out of the
   reproductive system and the tiny spermatozoa lacking a visible
   flagellum, suggest they belong to a new genus, possibly in the family
   Macrodasyidae. These hypotheses are supported by the phylogenetic
   relationships of 47 taxa inferred from analyses of the 185 rRNA gene,
   which found the new species clustering with Thaidasys tongiorgii in a
   subset of a larger Glade containing Macrodasys. Accordingly, the
   establishment of the following taxa is proposed: Kryptodasys gen. nov.,
   K. marcocurinii sp. nov., K. carlosrochai sp. nov. and K. ulfjondeliusi
   sp. nov.
C1 Todaro, M. Antonio; Univ Modena & Reggio Emilia, Dipartimento Sci Vita,
   Via Giuseppe Campi 213-D, Modena, I-41125, Italy, Italy.
EM antonio.todaro@unimore.it
RI ; Todaro, M. Antonio/H-1311-2013
OI Dal Zotto, Matteo/0000-0003-1386-7626; Todaro, M.
   Antonio/0000-0002-6353-7281

SN 2045-2322

   North Atlantic

   Kryptodasys ulfjondeliusi [Baltic Sea / Sweden / New species]. 
   Macrodasyidae [Molecular genetics / 18S rRNA gene sequences /
   systematics] [Phylogeny /  / ].

TI A taxonomic review of the crab spider genus Sidymella (Araneae,
   Thomisidae) in the Neotropics.
AU Machado, Miguel
   Guzati, Catherine
   Viecelli, Rafaela
   Molina-Gomez, Diana
   Teixeira, Renato Augusto
SO Zoosystematics and Evolution
VL 95
IS 2
PS 319-344
PD May 29 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Four Neotropical species of Sidymella Strand, 1942, S. furcillata
   Keyserling, 1880, S. longispina (Mello-Leitao, 1943), S. lucida
   (Keyserling, 1880), and S. kolpogaster (Lise, 1973) are redescribed from
   both sexes. The holotype of S. nigripes (Mello-Leitao, 1947) is lost and
   this taxon is considered a species inquierenda. Sidymella obscura
   (Mello-Leitao, 1929), S. parallela (Mello-Leitao, 1929), and S.
   spinifera (Mello-Leitao, 1929) are all nomina dubia. Two new species are
   described: Sidymella excavata sp. nov. (males and females) and S.
   marmorata sp. nov. (female).

DT Article
TI Rhyacoschistura larreci, a new genus and species of loach from Laos and
   redescription of R. suber (Teleostei: Nemacheilidae).
AU Kottelat, Maurice (mkottelat@dplanet.ch) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 2
PS 151-170
PD May 29 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Rhyacoschistura, new genus, belongs to a group of genera
   (Physoschistura, Mustura, Pteronemacheilus, Petruichthys) characterised
   by the modified branched pectoral-fin rays of males, with a very thick
   first ray, usually without membranes between some of the branches and/or
   rays, and anterior rays and/or membranes covered by small tubercles at
   maturity. Rhyacoschistura is distinguished from them by the combination
   of: presence of a suborbital flap; emarginate caudal fin; lower lip with
   a wide median interruption and connected to isthmus by a frenum; body
   depth about equal from behind head to caudal-fin base. Rhyacoschistura
   larreci, new species, is described from the Mekong drainage in Xayaburi
   Province, Laos. It is distinguished by details of the morphology of the
   pelvic fin, and its colour pattern (flank with numerous narrow slanted
   bars, very irregularly organised and shaped, more or less connected, or
   sometimes covering the whole flank). Schistura suber, from Nam Ngum
   watershed, is redescribed on the basis of adults and placed in
   Rhyacoschistura.
C1 Kottelat, Maurice; Rue Rauraques 6, Delemont, CH-2800, Switzerland,
   Switzerland.
EM mkottelat@dplanet.ch
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Rhyacoschistura larreci [Laos /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cypriniformes, Balitoridae
OR Rhyacoschistura (Cypriniformes): [Gen nov, Of family Nemacheilidae, Type
   species Rhyacoschistura larreci, p. 152]. 
   Rhyacoschistura larreci (Cypriniformes): [Sp nov, Laos, P. 159]. 
   Rhyacoschistura suber - (Kottelat 2000) (Cypriniformes): [Redescription,
   P. 162; Comb nov, Transferred from Schistura, p. 161]. 
   Schistura suber - Kottelat 2000 (Balitoridae): [Referred to, New genus
   Rhyacoschistura, p. 161]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15508052290
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI DNA barcodes and morphology revealed three species masquerading in
   Xiphydria camelus of authors (Hymenoptera, Xiphydriidae) in Northeast
   Asia: X. eborata sp. rev. and X. albopicta sp. nov.
AU Shinohara, Akihiko (shinohar@kahaku.go.jp) 
   Kameda, Yuichi
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 2
PS 171-186
PD May 29 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Taxonomic status of the widely spread xiphydriid woodwasp Xiphydria
   camelus (Linne, 1758) was revised by examining morphology of 964
   specimens and by molecular analysis using COI barcode sequences. Both
   morphological and molecular approaches indicated existence of three
   separate species masquerading in X. camelus of authors in East Asia. The
   three species were finally determined as X. camelus, X. eborata Konow,
   1899, and a new species, X. albopicta. Xiphydria eborata is revived from
   synonymy with X. camelus and X. albopicta is described as a new species
   from Russia (Primorskij Kraj), China (Heilongjiang) and Japan
   (Hokkaido). Collection records are given for all the specimens examined.
C1 Shinohara, Akihiko; Natl Museum Nat & Sci, Dept Zool, 4-1-1 Amakubo,
   Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 3050005, Japan, Japan.
EM shinohar@kahaku.go.jp
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Genetics &Heredity; Parasitology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; General
   morphology; Genetics; Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

   [Molecular genetics / mtDNA COI barcoding / ] [Asia / East / ]. 
   Xiphydria albopicta [Plant hosts / Betula platyphylla var. japonica /
   New parasite species] [Russia /  / New species] [Heilongjiang /  / ]
   [Japan /  / New species from plant host].

   Xiphydria albopicta (Xiphydriidae): [Sp nov, Japan, Parasite of Betula
   platyphylla var. japonica (Plant), p. 175; Parasite]. 
   Xiphydria camelus - (Linnaeus 1758) (Xiphydriidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, Xiphydria eborata Konow 1899, p. 176]. 
   Xiphydria eborata - Konow 1899 (Xiphydriidae): [Removal from synonymy,

DT Article
TI Taxonomy of the 'Afroeudesis group' of glandulariine ant-like stone
   beetles (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Scydmaeninae).
AU Jaloszynski, Pawel (scydmaenus@yahoo.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 2
PS 205-220
PD May 29 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Among the currently recognized 71 extant genera of Glandulariini,
   Afroeudesis Franz shows an unusual distribution, with strikingly similar
   species known from South America, west and east Africa, and the
   sub-Himalayan region of Asia. Morphological studies revealed that
   several species placed in other genera share with Afroeudesis several
   unique characters, among others a symmetrical pattern of numerous setae
   on the frons and vertex, not known in any other Glandulariini. This
   'Afroeudesis group' is here recognized to be composed of the Neotropical
   genera Meridaphes Jaloszynski, Stenichnoconnus Franz and Pseudoraphes
   Franz, the broadly distributed Afroeudesis, and the Neotropical
   Bicarinulodes gen. n. The last is proposed for a species previously
   misplaced in Microscydmus Saulcy & Croissandeau, resulting in
   Bicarinulodes meridensis (Franz) comb. n. Bicarinulodes is most similar
   to Afroeudesis, but (among other differences) it lacks the apomorphy
   that is unique for the latter genus, the raised subtriangular 'platform'
   on the frons and vertex. Stenichnoconnus minor (Franz), comb. n is
   proposed for Euconnus minor (Franz), originally published as
   Venezolanoconnus minor Franz. Stenichnoconnus and Pseudoraphes are
   redefined and redescribed.
C1 Jaloszynski, Pawel; Univ Wroclaw, Museum Nat Hist, Sienkiewicza 21,
   Wroclaw, PL-50335, Poland, Poland.
EM scydmaenus@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Diagnosis;
   Description; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Zoogeography

TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,

   Afroeudesis group (Scydmaenidae). 
   Bicarinulodes (Scydmaenidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Glandulariini, Type
   species Microscydmus meridensis Franz 1988, p. 214]. 
   Bicarinulodes meridensis - (Franz 1988) (Scydmaenidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Microscydmus, p. 217]. 
   Euconnus minor - (Franz 1988) (Scydmaenidae): [Referred to,
   Stenichnoconnus, p. 211]. 
   Meridaphes - Jaloszynski 2015 (Scydmaenidae): [Emended diagnosis, P.
   208].

   Redescription, P. 213].

   Redescription, P. 210]. 
   Stenichnoconnus minor - (Franz 1988) (Scydmaenidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Euconnus, p. 211].

DT Article
TI Towards the taxonomy of Corynoneura Winnertz (Diptera: Chironomidae:
   Orthocladiinae) from the Russian Far East and Eastern Siberia.
AU Makarchenko, Eugenyi A. (makarchenko@biosoil.ru) 
   Makarchenko, Marina A.
   Semenchenko, Alexander A.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 2
PS 221-236
PD May 29 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The genus Corynoneura Winnertz is partly revised on the basis of
   materials from the Russian Far East and Eastern Siberia. Adult male of a
   new species, C. sikhotealinensis sp. nov., as well as pupa of C. schleei
   Makarchenko et Makarchenko and pupa with associated pharate male of
   Corynoneura sp. are described. Adult male of C. fujiundecima Sasa,
   earlier erroneously determined as C. lacustris Edwards, is briefly
   redescribed and annotated. DNA barcoding results of C. kadalinka
   Makarchenko et Makarchenko from Eastern Siberia (Baikal Lake basin) are
   also provided in comparison with closely related C. carriana Edwards
   from Sweden. As a result of the analysis, supported with sufficiently
   significant morphological differences between males of these two distant
   populations, the two species were combined into one, C. carriana, with
   two subspecies: C. carriana carriana Edwards (nominotypical) and C.
   carriana kadalinka Makarchenko et Makarchenko stat. nov. A morphological
   redescriptions of the adult male and pupa, as well as the 4th instar
   larva (here described for the first time) of C. carriana kadalinka in
   comparison with specimens of populations of the C. carriana carriana
   from Sweden and the Urals are presented. A key to adult males and pupae
   of the Corynoneura species from the Russian Far East and Eastern Siberia
   is also provided.

   Vladivostoku 159, Vladivostok, 690022, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI Description of a new species of Spongiopsyllus Johnsson, 2000, and
   redescriptions of Parmulodes verrucosus Wilson, 1944 and Entomopsyllus
   stocki Kim, 2004 with revised diagnosis of Entomopsyllus (Copepoda,
   Siphonostomatoida, Entomolepididae).
AU Canario, Roberta
   Hurbath, Thiego
   Da Rocha, Carlos E.F.
   Neves, Elizabeth G.
   Johnsson, Rodrigo (r.johnsson@gmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 2
PS 247-259
PD May 29 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Family Entomolepididae is composed by 7 genera and 15 species.
   During a survey on the known species and the search for new species, a
   new Spongiopsyllus is described associated with sponge Aplysina
   insularis. The new species has antennule 14-segmented, four setae on
   both lobes of maxillule, some unique features on the leg setation and
   the armature of the maxilliped. These characteristics make the new
   species different from all other congeners in Spongiopsyllus. The
   diagnosis of Entomopsyllus was also revised once it does not consider
   the differences to Spongiopsyllus which was created posteriorly to its
   erection. An analysis of Entomopsyllus stocki also indicated that leg 5
   somite and the genital somite are fused, instead of separated as
   originally stated, the structure is also redescribed. Finally,
   Parmulodes verrucosus is studied and an up-to-date description is
   provided, correcting some inconsistencies in the armature formula of the
   antennule and the leg setation, and providing re-analysis of the other
   appendages.
C1 Johnsson, Rodrigo; Univ Fed Bahia, Inst Biol, Av Adhemar Barros
   S-N,Campus Ondina, Salvador, BA, BR-40170290 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM r.johnsson@gmail.com
RI Neves, Elizabeth G./K-2044-2012

SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Associations; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean

   New associate species] [South Atlantic / Brazil / New associated
   crustacean species]. 
   Spongiopsyllus atypicus [Associations / Aplysina insularis (Porifera) /
   New associate species] [South Atlantic / Brazil / New species; poriferan
   associate]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates; Sponges
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Copepoda, Siphonostomatoida, Porifera,
   Demospongiae

PM 31717072
DT Article
TI Description of Penia mantillerii sp. nov. (Coleoptera: Elateridae:
   Dimini), with a key to Penia species from Vietnam and nearby areas.
AU Kundrata, Robin (robin.kundrata@upol.cz) 
   Nemeth, Tamas
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 2
PS 275-281
PD May 29 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 3
AB Penia Laporte, 1838 is the most species-rich genus in the click-beetle
   tribe Dimini. Penia is distributed in the Himalayas, East and South East
   Asia. In this paper, we describe P. mantillerii sp. nov. from northern
   Vietnam. This species is easily recognizable due to its elongate body
   and large window-like elytral punctures. The most morphologically
   similar species to P. mantillerii sp. nov. are P. costipennis Fleutiaux,
   1936 and P. sucinea Schimmel, 2001, which also occur in northern
   Vietnam. Male pregenital segments and genitalia are figured for the
   first time for P. sucinea. An identification key to the Penia species
   from Vietnam and surroundings is provided.
C1 Kundrata, Robin; Palacky Univ, Fac Sci, 17 Listopadu 50, Olomouc, 77146,
   Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM robin.kundrata@upol.cz
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Penia [China /  / Key to species] [Laos /  / ] [Vietnam /  / ]. 
   Penia mantillerii [Vietnam /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Elateroidea,
   Elateridae
OR Penia - Laporte 1838 (Elateridae): [Key to species, China, Laos &
   Vietnam, P. 280]. 
   Penia mantillerii (Elateridae): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 276]. 
   Penia sucinea - Schimmel 2001 (Elateridae): [First time figured, Male
   pregenital segments & genitalia, p. 279].

LA English

AB The Latithorax Species Group of Velarifictorus contains a number of
   species that are small and possess a stick-shaped ectoparamere of the
   epiphallus. Here, three new taxa of this group from China are described
   and illustrated. These are: Velarifictorus agitatus shaanxiensis sp. and
   subsp. nov., V. a. yunnanensis subsp. nov., V. stultus sp. nov.

DT Article
TI First nesting description of the Streaked Dacnis (Xenodacnis petersi) in
   Ecuador.
FT Primera descripcion sobre la anidacion del Dacnis andino norteno
   (xenodacnis petersi) en Ecuador.
AU Molina Abril, Paul (paulgesnam@gmail.com) 
   Carrasco Ugalde, Agustin
   Iniguez Vela, Xavier
   Malo Larrea, Antonio
SO Ornitologia Neotropical
VL 30
PS 79-83
PD May 28 2019
PY 2019
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Here we report new information on the reproductive biology of the
   Streaked Dacnis (Xenodacnis petersi). In Ecuador, this species is found
   in the high Andes, mainly in Cajas National Park, where we found five
   nests between September 2017 and November 2018. The cup-shaped nests
   were built on four different plants, with the pubescence of flowers of
   Puya sp., moss, straw and dry branches as the main materials. Clutch
   size was one or two eggs and these were laid on consecutive days. The
   female was in charge of the incubation, while both sexes took care of
   the chicks. Incubation lasted between 17 to 20 days, and the chicks
   remained in the nest for 16 to 18 days.
C1 Molina Abril, Paul; Consultores Ambientales Gesnam Cia Ltda, Sucre 3-12,
   Cuenca, Ecuador, Ecuador.
EM paulgesnam@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Reproductive Biology
SN 1075-4377
BD Reproduction; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Xenodacnis petersi [Reproduction / First nesting description / ]
   [Ecuador / Cajas National Park / ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Passeriformes, Emberizidae
OR Xenodacnis petersi (Emberizidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15603021816
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15602007508
PM 31182905
DT Article
TI Annotated nomenclator of extant and fossil taxa of the Paludomidae
   (Caenogastropoda, Cerithioidea).
AU Neiber, Marco T. (marco-thomas.neiber@uni-hamburg.de) 
   Glaubrecht, Matthias
SO ZooKeys
VL 850
PS 1-132
PD May 28 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This nomenclator provides bibliographic details on all names in the
   family-, genus-, and species-group of the the family Paludomidae. All
   nomenclaturally available names are discussed including junior homonyms
   and objective junior synonyms as well as unavailable names such as
   nomina nuda, infrasubspecific names and, to some extent, also incorrect
   subsequent spellings. In the family-group a total of 28 names are
   included in the nomenclator, of which 21 are available and seven
   unavailable names. Of the available names in the family-group, six are
   invalid for nomenclatural reasons. In the genus-group a total of 57
   names are included in the catalogue. Of the available names in the
   genus-group, 11 are invalid for nomenclatural reasons. In the
   species-group a total of 499 names are included, of which 463 are
   available, but 21 are invalid for nomenclatural reasons. All names are
   given in their original combination and spelling (mandatory changes are
   discussed and corrected spellings are provided), along with the
   reference to the original publication. For each family- and genus-group
   name, the original classification and the type genus or type species,
   respectively, are given. For species-group taxa the type locality and
   type horizon (for fossil taxa) are provided, usually as given in the
   original publication. A new name, Cleopatra adami nom. nov., is proposed
   for the fossil Cleopatra cylindrica (Adam, 1957), which is a homonym of
   Cleopatra cridlandi cylindrica Mandahl-Barth, 1954, and a lectotype for
   Cleopatra dubia Adam, 1959 is designated. A new replacement name
   Leloupiella nom. nov. is proposed for Stormsia Leloup, 1953 which is a
   homonym of Stormsia Bourguignat, 1891.
C1 Neiber, Marco T.; Univ Hamburg, Zool Museum, Martin Luther King Pl 3,
   Hamburg, D-20146, Germany, Germany.
EM marco-thomas.neiber@uni-hamburg.de
RI Neiber, Marco T./AAH-2864-2019
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Combination; Spelling;
   Available name; Unavailable name; Priority; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Status; Documentation; Publications
DE Paludomidae [Catalogues /  / Systematics; extant & fossil taxa]
   [Nomenclators / Annotated nomenclator / ].

   Neritoidea, Mesogastropoda, Cerithioidea, Rissoidea, Viviparoidea,
   Pulmonata, Stylommatophora, Helicoidea

PT J
AN ZOOR15509059697
DT Article
TI Apicoporus haificum (Gymnodiniaceae), a new dinoflagellate species from
   sandy sediments of tie Mediterranean Sea (Israel coast).
AU Krakhmalnyi, Maxim A.
   Krakhmalnyi, Aleksandr F. (maximkrakhm@gmail.com) 
SO Phytotaxa
VL 404
IS 7
PS 287-291
PD May 28 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB A new dinoflagellate species (Dinophyceae, Gymnodiniales)-Apicoporus
   haificum Krachmalny sp. nov. was described on a basis of thorough light
   microscopy studies. The species was found in sandy sediments
   (water-filled spaces between sand grains) on the eastern coast of the
   Mediterranean Sea (HaCarmel beach, Haifa, Israel). Apicoporus haificum
   possesses the following features: cells elongated (with length exceeding
   width by 3.1-3.8 times), lanceolate in dorsoventral projection, roundish
   in cross-section with slight dorsoventral compression, asymmetrical,
   slightly curved to the right, with antapical depression. Epicone
   asymmetrical, somewhat umbonate, with a small hook-shaped protrusion on
   the apex. Cingulum displaced, descending by 1/3 cell's length, its
   distal part almost parallel to the anterior portion of sulcus. Sulcus
   narrow, shallow, extends from the apex to the antapical depression, with
   apical groove. Cell surface covered with longitudinal striations that
   converge on the apex and on the antapical protrusion. Chloroplasts
   absent. Dimensions: 75.3[plus or minus]2.2 [mu]m in length, 21.4[plus or
   minus]1.5 [mu]m in width. Comparison of A. haificum to morphologically
   similar Apicoporus glaber and Amphidinium scissum is discussed.
C1 Krakhmalnyi, Aleksandr F.; NAS Ukraine, Inst Evolutionary Ecol, 37 Acad
   Lebedeva Str, Kiev, UA-03143, Ukraine, Ukraine.
EM maximkrakhm@gmail.com
RI Krakhmalnyi, Aleksandr/AAD-7984-2020; Krakhmalnyi, Maxim/AAE-5755-2020
SC Zoology
SN 1179-3155; 1179-3163
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North
   Atlantic
DE Apicoporus haificum [Mediterranean Sea / Israel / New species]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Mastigophora, Phytomastigophorea,
   Dinoflagellida
OR Apicoporus haificum (Dinoflagellida): [Sp nov, Israel (marine), P. 289].

PM 31179175
DT Article
TI The biogeography of Elaphe sauromates (Pallas, 1814), with a description
   of a new rat snake species.
AU Jablonski, Daniel (daniel.jablonski@balcanica.cz) 
   Kukushkin, Oleg, V
   Avci, Aziz
   Bunyatova, Sabina
   Kumlutas, Yusuf
   Ilgaz, Cetin
   Polyakova, Ekaterina
   Shiryaev, Konstantin
   Tuniyev, Boris
   Jandzik, David
SO PeerJ
VL 7
PS e6944
PD May 28 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Background: The rat snake genus Elaphe once comprised several dozens of
   species distributed in temperate through tropical zones of the New and
   Old World. Based on molecular-genetic analyses in early 2000s, the genus
   was split into several separate genera, leaving only 15 Palearctic and
   Oriental species as its members. One of the three species also occurring
   in Europe is Elaphe sauromates, a robust snake from the Balkans,
   Anatolia, Caucasus, Ponto-Caspian steppes, and Levant that has been
   suspected to be composed of two or more genetically diverse populations.
   Here, we studied the genetic structure and morphological variation of E.
   sauromates, aiming to better understand its inter-population
   relationships and biogeography, and subsequently revise its taxonomy.
   Methods: We reconstructed the phylogeography and analyzed the genetic
   structure of E. sauromates populations originating from most of its
   geographic range using both mitochondrial (COI, ND4) and nuclear (C-MOS,
   MC1R, PRLR, RAG1) DNA gene fragments. We employed Maximum likelihood and
   Bayesian inference methods for the phylogenetic tree reconstructions,
   supplemented with species delimitation methods, analysis of haplotype
   networks, and calculation of uncorrected p-distances. Morphological
   variation in 15 metric and 18 meristic characters was studied using
   parametric univariate tests as well as multivariate general linearized
   models. In total, we analyzed sequences originating from 63 specimens
   and morphological data from 95 specimens of E. sauromates sensu lato.
   Results: The molecular phylogeny identified two clearly divergent sister
   lineages within E. sauromates, with both forming a lineage sister to E.
   quatuorlineata. The genetic distance between them (5.80-8.24% in mtDNA)
   is similar to the distances among several other species of the genus
   Elaphe. Both lineages are also moderately morphologically differentiated
   and, while none of the characters are exclusively diagnostic, their
   combination can be used for confident lineage identification. Here,
   following the criteria of genetic and evolutionary species concepts, we
   describe the lineage from eastern Anatolia and parts of the Lesser and
   Great Caucasus as a new species E. urartica sp. nov. Discussion: Elaphe
   urartica sp. nov. represents a cryptic species whose ancestors
   presumably diverged from their common ancestor with E. sauromates around
   the Miocene-Pliocene boundary. The intraspecific genetic structure
   indicates that the recent diversity of both species has been
   predominantly shaped by Pleistocene climatic oscillations, with glacial
   refugia mainly located in the Balkans, Crimea, and/or Anatolia in E.
   sauromates and Anatolia and/or the Caucasus in E. urartica sp. nov.
C1 Jablonski, Daniel; Comenius Univ Bratislava, Dept Zool, Bratislava,
   Slovakia, Slovakia.
EM daniel.jablonski@balcanica.cz
RI Ilgaz, Cetin/P-6603-2019; Jablonski, Daniel/AAT-7357-2020
OI Jablonski, Daniel/0000-0002-5394-0114
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 2167-8359
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Biometrics; Genetics;
   Evolution; Variation; Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Elaphe sauromates [Biometrics / Metric & meristic characters / taxonomic
   implications] [Molecular genetics / Mitochondrial & nuclear gene
   sequences / ] [Population genetics / Population genetic structure / ]
   [Phylogeny / Phylogeography / ] [Morphological variation /  / ]
   [Zoogeography /  / ] [Eurasia /  / ]. 
   Elaphe urartica [Russia /  / New species] [Turkey /  / ] [Armenia /  / ]
   [Azerbaijan /  / ] [Georgia-Asia /  / ] [Iran /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Serpentes, Colubridae
OR Elaphe sauromates - (Pallas 1814) (Colubridae): [Diagnostic characters,
   Scale counts, p. 19]. 
   Elaphe urartica - Jablonski et al. 2019 (Colubridae): [Sp nov, Turkey,
   P. 22]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15508052251
OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15508052206
PM 31717076
DT Article
TI A revision of Callulops doriae (Anura: Microhylidae), with descriptions
   of four new species.
AU Kraus, Fred (fkraus@umich.edu) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 1
PS 1-28
PD May 28 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB I investigate the taxonomy of frogs currently assigned to the single
   species Callulops doriae, which is unique in the genus for its warty,
   dark-spotted dorsum and large yellow or orange blotches in the groin and
   on the hidden surfaces of the thighs. I show that many species are
   currently encompassed under this single name, I remove Manthophryne
   neuhaussi from synonymy, and I describe four new species, three of which
   have long been in museum collections, and one of which is newly
   collected by me. Each of these new species is most readily distinguished
   by their unique color patterns, but additional morphological
   features-primarily morphometric-also serve to distinguish among them.
   Despite this partition of C. doriae, additional museum specimens cannot
   be assigned to any of the species treated here and certainly represent
   unrecognized species. But the poor states of preservation of some of
   these and the absence of color-pattern information in life preclude
   describing them until new material of each is available. Three of the
   six species treated herein, which occur in the southern portion of the
   Papuan Peninsula, were previously included in a molecular phylogeny, and
   inferred dates of divergence for them accord well with the geological
   dynamism of this region created by opening of the Woodlark Rift. In two
   cases, pairs of species are reported in general sympatry, and
   elevational data suggest that these species are likely to segregate
   elevationally where their ranges approach each other. At least four of
   the species treated herein are known to produce viscous glandular
   secretions that presumably deter predators, and I describe the defensive
   display of one of these, which I presume is aposematic.
C1 Kraus, Fred; Univ Michigan, Dept Ecol & Evolutionary Biol, Ann Arbor,
   MI, 48109, USA, USA.
EM fkraus@umich.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Biometrics; Colour and luminescence; Colour; Evolution; Variation;
   Morphological variation; Land zones; Australasian region; Australasia
DE Callulops argus; Callulops bicolor; Callulops stellatus; Callulops
   taxispilotus [Papua New Guinea /  / New species]. 
   Callulops doriae [Biometrics / Morphometrics / taxonomic revision]
   [Markings / Colour patterns / ] [Colour variation /  / ] [Papua New
   Guinea /  / distribution]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates

   Microhylidae
OR Callulops argus (Microhylidae): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P. 11]. 
   Callulops bicolor (Microhylidae): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P. 12]. 
   Callulops doriae - Boulenger 1888 (Microhylidae): [Emended diagnosis, P.
   3; Redescription, P. 3; Removal from synonymy, Callulops neuhaussi (Vogt
   1911), p. 10].

   synonymy, With Callulops doriae Boulenger 1888, p. 10].

PM 31717077
DT Article
TI Review of the Oxynoemacheilus tigris group with the description of two
   new species from the Euphrates drainage (Teleostei: Nemacheilidae).
AU Freyhof, Joerg (j.freyhof@igb-berlin.de) 
   Kaya, Cuneyt
   Turan, Davut
   Geiger, Matthias
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 1
PS 29-57
PD May 28 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 4
AB The Oxynoemacheilus tigris species group is reviewed, resulting in the
   recognition of six species, of which two are described herein as new.
   Oxynoemacheilus tigris is known from the endorheic Qweik River and the
   Merziman River, which is a tributary of the western Euphrates.
   Oxynoemacheilus ercisianus is endemic to the endorheic Lake Van basin
   and O. hazarensis is endemic to Lake Hazar basin in the upper Tigris
   drainage. Oxynoemacheilus kaynaki is widespread in the Euphrates
   drainage. The two undescribed species occur in the Euphrates drainage.
   Oxynoemacheilus arsaniasus, new species, from the Murat River and the
   upper Karasu (Mus) River drainage, is distinguished from other species
   of the O. tigris group by having a bold, black, irregularly-shaped bar
   at the caudal-fin base, an incomplete lateral line and a scaleless body.
   Oxynoemacheilus muefiti, new species, from the upper Murat River
   drainage and a tributary to the Ataturk reservoir, is most similar to O.
   ercisianus, from which it is distinguished by a more slender body and a
   shallower dorsal adipose crest. According to our molecular data, the
   Qweik population of O. tigris is suspected to be introgressed by O.
   namiri from the Orontes drainage. Oxynoemacheilus erdali is identified
   as a synonym of O. bergianus as we were unable to find differences
   between the two species.
C1 Freyhof, Joerg; Leibniz Inst Freshwater Ecol & Inland Fisheries I,
   Berlin, D-12587, Germany, Germany.
EM j.freyhof@igb-berlin.de
SC Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology

   Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia

   basin / Key to species].

   species]. 
   Oxynoemacheilus kaynaki [Turkey / Kaynarca & Gul streams / New record]. 
   Oxynoemacheilus tigris [Turkey / Euphrates drainage / New record;
   systematics]. 
   Oxynoemacheilus tigris species group [Molecular genetics / Mt COI gene
   sequences / taxonomic review] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Asia / Middle East / ].
   
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates

   Cypriniformes, Balitoridae

   Qweik River drainages & Lake Van basin, P. 34].

   Oxynoemacheilus bergianus (Balitoridae): [Syn nov, Oxynoemacheilus
   erdali, p. 33].

   [New record]. 
   Oxynoemacheilus muefiti (Balitoridae): [Sp nov, Turkey, P. 48]. 
   Oxynoemacheilus tigris - (Heckel 1843) (Balitoridae): [New record]. 
   Oxynoemacheilus tigris species group (Balitoridae).

DT Article
TI Gynacantha vargasi (Odonata: Anisoptera: Aeshnidae) sp. nov. from Costa
   Rica.
AU Haber, William A. (bill.haber01@gmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 1
PS 58-70
PD May 28 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The male and female of Gynacantha vargasi sp. nov. are described from
   three sites on the Caribbean slope of Costa Rica. The species is
   distinguished from its congeners by lime-green lateral thoracic stripes,
   orange-brown hind femur tipped with black, dorsal side of the hind tibia
   yellow, unique cercus shape, diurnal behavior, and barcode analysis. A
   key to all species of Gynacantha recorded from Mexico and Central
   America is provided.

TI Taxonomic and nomenclatorial revision within the Neotropical genera of
   the subtribe Odontocheilina W. Horn in a new sense-21. Pentacomia
   paranigrimarginata sp. nov. and P. nigrimarginata Huber with revised key
   to Pentacomia species (Coleoptera: Cicindelidae).
AU Moravec, Jiri (jirmor@quick.cz) 
   Brzoska, David
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 1
PS 71-84
PD May 28 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Pentacomia Bates, 1872 (restored to the
   original concept of the genus by Moravec 2018a) is described from
   Bolivia as P. paranigrimmginata sp. nov. The new species is compared to
   P. nigrimarginata Huber, 1999 of which the differential diagnosis and
   redescription are also given. Both species are illustrated with colour
   photographs of the habitus and diagnostic characters. A revised key to
   12 recognized species of Pentacomia with illustrative figures of
   important diagnostic characters is given.

DT Article
TI Morphology and DNA barcodes of two species of Bradysia Winnertz from
   China (Diptera, Sciaridae), with the description of Bradysia minorlobus
   Yang, Shi & Huang sp. n.
AU Yang, Xue
   Shi, Kai
   Heller, Kai
   Menzel, Frank
   Huang, Junhao (kaiheller@gmx.de) 
   Wu, Hong
SO Zootaxa
VL 4612
IS 1
PS 85-94
PD May 28 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two morphologically similar species of the fungicola species group of
   Bradysia Winnertz, 1867 were studied in China: Bradysia chenjinae Yang,
   Zhang & Yang, 1993 and Bradysia minorlobus Yang, Shi & Huang sp. n. The
   morphological species concepts were supported by the DNA barcodes of COI
   sequences. The genetic distances of 16 Bradysia fungicola group species
   were analyzed and a neighbor-joining tree was constructed. The
   morphological characters of both Chinese species were described and
   illustrated.
C1 Huang, Junhao; Zhejiang A & F Univ, Sch Forestry & Biotechnol, 88
   Huancheng Beilu, Hangzhou, Zhejiang, 311300, China, China.
EM kaiheller@gmx.de
RI huang, junhao/AAF-8734-2019
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; General morphology;
   Genetics; Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia;
   China

   characters / systematics] [Molecular genetics / Mt COI gene sequences /
   ] [Phylogeny /  / ].

DT Article
TI A new giant cricetine from the basal Pliocene of Mallorca (Balearic
   Islands, western Mediterranean): biostratigraphic nexus with continental
   mammal zones.
AU Torres-Roig, Enric (etorres@imedea.uib-csic.es) 
   Agusti, Jordi
   Bover, Pere
   Alcover, Josep Antoni
SO Historical Biology
VL 31
IS 5
PS 559-573
PD May 28 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new insular giant species of Apocricetus (M1 length > 4.22 mm, upper
   teeth row length > 10.90 mm) is described from dental, mandibular and
   cranial material recovered at the Na Burguesa-1 site (Mallorca, Balearic
   Islands, western Mediterranean), a Zanclean palaeokarst deposit
   chronologically close to the refilling of the Mediterranean after the
   Messinian Salinity Crisis. Apocricetus darderi sp. nov. shows a close
   relationship with the mainland species A. alberti (MN13), an Iberian
   taxon, from which it differs in size, the presence of labial and lingual
   anterolophids in m1, triple anterolophulids frequently developed, a
   reduced anterosinusid in m2 and m3 and, occasionally, the presence of an
   ectomesolophid in m3. Apocricetus darderi sp. nov. becomes the first
   endemic Balearic mammal that can be confidently assigned as having a
   direct mainland relative, providing the first solid palaeontological
   evidence of a Messinian origin for the Plio-Pleistocene fauna of
   Mallorca. Tragomys macpheei from the Calo den Rafelino site (Early
   Pliocene, probably late MN14 or early MN15) displays a peculiar
   selenodont teeth pattern and a high degree of hypsodonty, and is
   considered to be either a direct descendant of Apocricetus darderi sp.
   nov. or a sister taxon derived from a common ancestor.
C1 Torres-Roig, Enric; Inst Mediterrani Estudis Avancats, Dept
   Biodiversitat & Conservacio, Esporles, Spain, Spain.
EM etorres@imedea.uib-csic.es
RI Alcover, Josep Antoni/Y-3796-2018
OI Alcover, Josep Antoni/0000-0001-9905-2588; Bover Arbos,
   Pedro/0000-0003-2942-2840; Torres-Roig, Enric/0000-0003-0221-2448
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0891-2963
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Spain; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Neogene
DE Apocricetus darderi [Balearic Islands /  / new species] [Pliocene /  /
   ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Rodents; Vertebrates

   561; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Revision of Zaphanta Dyar, 1910 (Lepidoptera: Mimallonidae:
   Zaphantinae), with descriptions of nine new species.
AU St Laurent, Ryan A. (rstlaurent@flmnh.ufl.edu) 
   Giusti, Alessandro
SO Journal of Natural History
VL 53
IS 19-20
PS 1209-1246
PD May 27 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A genus of small, yellow mimallonid moths, Zaphanta Dyar, is revised.
   This genus has been shown to be sister to the remainder of Mimallonidae,
   and therefore has been placed in its own monogeneric subfamily,
   Zaphantinae St Laurent and Kawahara. Long considered monotypic or
   bitypic, Zaphanta have not been the focus of any systematic treatment.
   The moths belonging to this genus are found throughout Central and South
   America, and detailed examination of several disparate, as well as
   sympatric, populations of Zaphanta have revealed numerous undescribed
   species all of similar appearance, but with distinct male genitalia,
   which we describe here. We redescribe Z. infantilis Dyar and Z. fraterna
   Schaus, and describe the females of both for the first time. An
   additional nine new species are described and figured from the Amazon,
   Cerrado and Atlantic Forest: Z. acuta sp. nov., Z. anas sp. nov., Z.
   bahiana sp. nov., Z. beckeri sp. nov., Z. elephanta sp. nov., Z.
   elephanticula sp. nov., Z. machaera sp. nov., Z. rawlinsi sp. nov. and
   Z. stiletto sp. nov. One of these, Z. beckeri, may be extremely
   imperilled due to deforestation.
C1 St Laurent, Ryan A.; Univ Florida, Dept Biol, Gainesville, FL, 32611,
   USA, USA.
EM rstlaurent@flmnh.ufl.edu
OI St Laurent, Ryan/0000-0001-6439-5249
SC Zoology
SN 0022-2933
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Zaphanta [Neotropical region /  / Taxonomic revision]. 
   Zaphanta acuta; Zaphanta anas; Zaphanta bahiana; Zaphanta beckeri;
   Zaphanta elephanta; Zaphanta elephanticula; Zaphanta machaera; Zaphanta
   stiletto [Brazil /  / New species]. 
   Zaphanta rawlinsi [Ecuador /  / New species] [Peru /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans

   Mimallonoidea, Mimallonidae

   morphology, p. 1215]. 
   Zaphanta acuta (Mimallonidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 1236]. 
   Zaphanta anas (Mimallonidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 1227]. 
   Zaphanta bahiana (Mimallonidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 1243].

DT Article
TI New dung beetle genus and species from a cave in the Espinhaco mountain
   range, Brazil (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Scarabaeinae).
AU Pacheco, T.L. (thay.lpacheco@gmail.com) 
   Vaz-de-Mello, F.Z.
SO Journal of Natural History
VL 53
IS 19-20
PS 1247-1253
PD May 27 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Based on a single specimen collected in a cave in the municipality of
   Diamantina, state of Minas Gerais, Brazil, we describe Isacanthon
   mariaelinae Pacheco and Vaz-de-Mello, a new genus and species of dung
   beetles. The new genus is closely related to Paracanthon,
   Paracryptocanthon, Cryptocanthon and Tesserodoniella, but it can be
   distinguished by clypeus with two teeth, which appear to originate
   beneath clypeal margin, and metatibiae with one distinct tooth at basal
   two-fifth.

   Brazil.

DT Article
TI A revision of Australian Pectinariidae (Polychaeta), with new species
   and new records.
AU Zhang, Jinghuai (zhangjinghuai@sohu.com) 
   Hutchings, Pat
SO Zootaxa
VL 4611
IS 1
PS 1-70
PD May 27 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Samples of Pectinariidae in the Australian Museum and Museums of
   Victoria, Australia were examined. Thirteen species were identified,
   including three additional records of previously recorded species of
   Amphictene and two new species, A. cercusa n. sp. and A. undulata n.
   sp., two species of the genus Lagis which has not previously been
   recorded from Australia, including a new species, L. portus n. sp., and
   five additional records of previously recorded species of Pectinaria and
   one new species, P ningalooensis n. sp. The study revealed additional
   characters which are useful to identify species of pectinariids, a pair
   of ear-shaped lobes which are adjacent to both sides of dorsal base of
   cephalic veil in species of Pectinaria and Amphictene, but in Lagis they
   are present between the buccal cavity and lateral margin of segment 1;
   and a pair of ventral lappets which have not previously been described
   on the lateral margin of segment I in all species of pectinariids from
   Australia. For species where numerous individuals were available for
   study, we investigated how some characters, change with increasing body
   size. A key to all recorded species from Australia is given, but does
   not imply any phylogenetic relationships.
C1 Zhang, Jinghuai; State Ocean Adm, South China Sea Environm Monitoring
   Ctr, 155 Xingangxi Rd, Guangzhou, Guangdong, China, China.
EM zhangjinghuai@sohu.com

DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Dziriblatta Chopard, 1936 (Blattodea, Ectobiidae,
   Ectobiinae) from North Africa, Spain, and the Macaronesian islands. I.
   The nine subgenera of the genus.
AU Bohn, Horst (bohn@zi.biologie.uni-muenchen.de) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4610
IS 1
PS 1-73
PD May 27 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 1
U2 2
AB An initial contribution to the revision of the genus Dziriblatta
   Chopard, 1936a, formerly synonymized erroneously with Lobolampra
   Houlbert, 1927, is presented. The species of the genus, hitherto placed
   in the subgenera Phyllodromica, Arbiblatta Chopard, 1936a and Lobolampra
   Houlbbert, 1927, of the genus Phyllodromica Fieber 1853, are distributed
   on the northern Macaronesian Islands, in southern Spain, North Africa,
   and the Near East (Israel, Cyprus). The genus is divided into nine new
   subgenera: Autumnoblatta subgen. nov., Blattantis subgen. nov.,
   Discieroblatta subgen. nov., Dziriblatta subgen. nov., Macaroblatta
   subgen. nov., Monoscleroblatta subgen. nov., Pauciscleroblatta subgen.
   nov., Sculptoblatta subgen. nov., and Sulcoblatta subgen. nov.. The
   characteristics of the genus and its subgenera are described including
   also a determination key which allows the discrimination of the
   subgenera in both sexes. The presumable phylogenetic position of the
   genus and the relationships between the subgenera are discussed and
   shown in cladograms. The described species and their distribution are
   shown in numerous figures and distribution maps, respectively. Three new
   species are described: Dziriblatta (Sculptoblatta) prisca spec. nov.,
   Dziriblatta (Autumnoblatta) nasuta spec. nov., and Dziriblatta
   (Macaroblatta) dendroglandulosa spec. nov. Nomenclatory changes: The
   species Blatta carpetana Bolivar, 1873, is designated as lectotype for
   the subgenus Lobolampra Houlbert, 1927. New synonyms: Aphlebia cazurroi
   Bolivar, 1885, is a junior synonym of Dziriblatta algerica (Bolivar,
   1881); Dziriblatta theryi Chopard, 1936a, Hololampra finoti Bolivar,
   1914, and Lobolampra adelungi Chopard, 1943, are synonyms of Dz.
   (Pauciscleroblatta) kroumiriensis (Adelung, 1914); Dz. vicina Chopard,
   1936b, is a synonym of Dz. (Monoscleroblatta) merrakescha (Adelung,
   1914).
C1 Bohn, Horst; Zool Staatssammlung, Munchhausenstr 21, Munich, D-81247,
   Germany, Germany.
EM bohn@zi.biologie.uni-muenchen.de
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Evolution; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Palaearctic region; Africa; Eurasia; Europe;
   Oceanic islands; Atlantic Ocean islands
DE Dziriblatta [Phylogeny /  / Taxonomic revision] [Africa / North Africa /

   Dziriblatta (Autumnoblatta) (Blattodea): [Subgen nov, Type species

   Dziriblatta (Discleroblatta) merrakescha - (Adelung 1914) (Blattodea):
   [Comb nov, Transferred from Lobolampra, p. 13; Syn nov, Dziriblatta
   vicina Chopard 1936, p. 14]. 
   Dziriblatta (Dziriblatta) - Chopard 1936 (Blattodea): [Diagnosis, P.

   Dziriblatta (Dziriblatta) algerica - (Bolivar 1881) (Blattodea): [Syn

DT Article
TI A New Species of Phaenoplana (Platyhelminthes: Polycladida) from the
   Ogasawara Islands.
AU Oya, Yuki (yoya@eis.hokudai.ac.jp) 
   Kajihara, Hiroshi
SO Species Diversity
VL 24
IS 1
PS 1-6
PD May 25 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We describe a new species of polyclad flatworm, Phaenoplana kopepe sp.
   nov., from Chichijima island in the Ogasawara Islands, Japan. This is
   the first report of Phaenoplana from Japan. Phaenoplana kopepe sp. nov.
   is characterized by i) a vagina that curves anteriorly, ii) gonopores
   well-separated from each other, and iii) a Lang's duct that is shorter
   than the vagina. We provide a partial sequence (610 bp) from the
   mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase subunit I gene as a DNA bar-code for
   the species.
C1 Oya, Yuki; Hokkaido Univ, Grad Sch Sci, Sapporo, Hokkaido, 0600810,
   Japan, Japan.
EM yoya@eis.hokudai.ac.jp
SC Zoology
SN 1342-1670
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Marine zones; Pacific
   Ocean
DE Phaenoplana [North Pacific / Japan / New record; systematics]. 
   Phaenoplana kopepe [North Pacific / Japan / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Platyhelminths
ST Animalia, Platyhelminthes, Turbellaria
OR Phaenoplana - Faubel 1983 (Turbellaria): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, Species, p. 5; New record]. 
   Phaenoplana kopepe (Turbellaria): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), P. 2]. 
   Stylochoplanidae - Meixner 1907 (Turbellaria): [Authorship, P. 2;
   Publication date, P. 2].

PT J

DT Article
TI First Record of Thysanophrys papillaris (Actynopterygii:
   Scorpaeniformes: Platycephalidae) from the Western Pacific.
AU Imamura, Hisashi (imamura@fish.hokudai.ac.jp) 
   Kimura, Katsuya
   Nguyen Van Quan
SO Species Diversity
VL 24
IS 1
PS 17-22
PD May 25 2019
PY 2019
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A single specimen of the platycephalid fish Thysanophrys papillaris
   Imamura and Knapp, 1999, collected from Nha Trang, Vietnam, represents
   the first record of the species from the western Pacific, previous
   records having been restricted to the Indian Ocean (Timor, Arafura and
   Andaman seas). Thysanophrys papillaris is separable from other members
   of the genus in having 11 second dorsal-fin rays, 12 anal-fin rays,
   58-75 oblique body scale rows slanting downward and forward below the
   lateral line, the snout longer than the orbital diameter (ratio of snout
   length/orbital diameter 1.1-1.3), a single (rarely 2) small papillae on
   the upper eye surface, the upper iris lappet with short branches, 1
   preorbital spine and 3-5 sub-orbital spines (usually 4). Thysanophrys
   haploblepharis Prokofiev, 2017, recently described from the western
   Indian Ocean, is regarded as a junior synonym of Suggrundus cooperi
   (Regan, 1908), also known from the western Indian Ocean.
C1 Imamura, Hisashi; Hokkaido Univ, Lab Marine Biol & Biodivers Systemat
   Ichthyol, 3-1-1 Minato Cho, Hakodate, Hokkaido, 0418611, Japan, Japan.
EM imamura@fish.hokudai.ac.jp
SC Zoology
SN 1342-1670
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Thysanophrys papillaris [Pacific Ocean /  / New record; systematics]
   [North Pacific / Vietnam / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Scorpaeniformes, Platycephalidae
OR Suggrundus cooperi - (Regan 1908) (Platycephalidae): [Syn nov,
   Thysanophrys haploblepharis Prokofiev 2017, p. 20]. 
   Thysanophrys papillaris - Imamura & Knapp 1999 (Platycephalidae): [New
   record].
